TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants are the son ( the first applicant ) , the daughter - in - law ( the second applicant ) and the wife ( the third applicant ) of DATE . They were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in PERSON , GPE . The first and the third applicants are also PERSON first heirs , according to the NORP civil law .
CARDINAL . The third applicant and PERSON ran a printing house and a small spirit factory as a family business .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON was charged with bribetaking and made an undertaking not to leave his residence . A truck and a television set belonging to him were seized . It appears that he then hired a defence lawyer .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating authority decided to dismiss the charge against PERSON for lack of evidence , lifted the seizure and cancelled the undertaking . It appears that after the dismissal of the charge , PERSON advocate refused to work with him any longer .
CARDINAL . In DATE PERSON and the third applicant sold the family business to a private person .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON instituted proceedings seeking compensation for wrongful prosecution . In particular , he claimed reimbursement for legal and transport costs . He also claimed compensation for the loss of his family business , alleging that as a result of the prosecution he could not run it and had to sell it at a low price .

CARDINAL . On DATE supplemented his claim , alleging that as a result of the prosecution the first and the second applicants had had to leave their jobs . The first and the second applicants also joined the proceedings as third parties having additional claims .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG granted the claim in part , ordering reimbursement of legal costs and part of the transport costs . As for the rest of the claim , ORG dismissed it on the ground that there was no causal link between the sale of the business and PERSON Ghuyumchyan ’s prosecution or between the first and the second applicants’ leaving their jobs and the prosecution .
CARDINAL . It appears that on DATE PERSON lodged a request with ORG , seeking to receive legal aid .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Chairman of ORG informed him in a letter that LAW did not provide for legal aid for the type of proceedings in which he was involved .
CARDINAL . On DATE lodged a complaint with ORG alleging that on DATE he had been beaten by the Head of the Lori Region of GPE . The outcome of this complaint is unclear .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date PERSON and the first applicant lodged an appeal against the judgment of ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG delivered its judgment upholding the judgment of ORG in respect of the reimbursement of part of the travel costs as well as legal fees , but dismissing the rest of the claim .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON lodged an appeal with ORG against the judgment of ORG .

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG of ORG returned the appeal , informing him that it had not been admitted for examination as it had not been lodged by an advocate licensed to act before ORG , pursuant to LAW . The applicants alleged before the ORG that their family could not afford the services of such an advocate .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON and also the first and the second applicants lodged an introductory letter with ORG in which they complained under LAW that PERSON had been denied access to ORG , under LAW ( c ) that PERSON ORG ’s defence lawyer had refused to represent him in the compensatory proceedings and that his request for legal aid had been rejected by ORG .
